linkTarget.anchoringText: However, after 6 months of production, the wellbore of H-8 was choked by colloid (Fig. 1) and tail gas failed to released efficiently. Finally, the THAI test was failed. After investigation, it may attribute to several factors: (1) the presence of shale barrier may block the chamber growth and impede oil drainage, (2) tail gas was not able to be produced efficiently by H-8 which may lead to unstable combustion, (3) it was not clear how colloid generated which choked the wellbore.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: colloid is choked in horizontal wellbore

formatted-caption.caption-text: colloid is choked in horizontal wellbore

linkTarget.anchoringText: In early stage, drainage areas increased step by step and then steam driving and oil drainage co-exist in the pilot well groups (Malik et al., 2010). However, the barrier distribution features will affect the method, for example, the continuity of the barrier (Gao et al., 2016). By comparing the CSS development features of the two reservoirs, curves the of production volume of each cycles and the OSRs are also very similar (Figure 2).

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Comparison of S1-3832 and X-VI CSS production performance.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Comparison of S1-3832 and X-VI CSS production performance.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Based on the lessons learned from the THAI trail, impermeable shale barriers and low-permeability zones are detrimental to steam chamber growth. In this study, detailed distributions of each layer are characterized and their maps are delineated. Two of the maps are shown in Figure 3. The brown regions represent the shale layers.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Shale layer distribution of two layers.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Shale layer distribution of two layers.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Then position and thickness data of the shale layers are digitized and imported to Petrel. Given special settings, the 3-D model of the shale layers are established (as shown in Figure 4). By accounting for geological and operation variances, numerical simulation method is adopted using CMG STARS (2014) to carry on optimum scheme of SAGD development of S1-3832 after history matching. Permeability and porosity numerical models are shown in Figure 5.

Then position and thickness data of the shale layers are digitized and imported to Petrel. Given special settings, the 3-D model of the shale layers are established (as shown in Figure 4). By accounting for geological and operation variances, numerical simulation method is adopted using CMG STARS (2014) to carry on optimum scheme of SAGD development of S1-3832 after history matching. Permeability and porosity numerical models are shown in Figure 5.

Simulation model has been adjusted according to development history. Simulations end by year of 2016, the results shows that the recovery factor is 20%, reservoir pressure is 2.0 MPa and oil saturation is 0.52, which satisfy the requirements of the SAGD transition. Temperature, oil saturation and pressure distributions are illustrated in Figure 6. To initial a SAGD process, a pre-heating (or start-up) process is needed. According to the temperature distribution, reservoir is not well heated.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Temperature, oil saturation and pressure distributions in 2016

formatted-caption.caption-text: Temperature, oil saturation and pressure distributions in 2016

linkTarget.anchoringText: According to experiences of injection test of Liaohe, curves of steam quality versus depth at different injection rates are plotted in Figure 7,indicating injection rate should be greater than 120t/d to ensure the desired steam quality (> 70%) at bottom hole. Insufficient injection rate will lead to low steam quality and less heat delivered to the formation, whereas high injection rate may result in an unfavorable manner along preferential paths of the steam, causing steam-channeling issues.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Recovery factor and OSR of different injection rates

formatted-caption.caption-text: Recovery factor and OSR of different injection rates

linkTarget.anchoringText: Insufficient injection rate will lead to low steam quality and less heat delivered to the formation, whereas high injection rate may result in an unfavorable manner along preferential paths of the steam, causing steam-channeling issues. To determine the optimum injection rate, different rate cases of 100t/d, 120t/d, 140t/d 160t/d and 180t/d are compared (shown in Figure 8), indicating 120t/d is the best rate.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Curves of steam quality versus depth at different injection rates

formatted-caption.caption-text: Curves of steam quality versus depth at different injection rates

linkTarget.anchoringText: Then, according to different ratios of production and injection rate, 1.0, 1.1, 1.2 and 1.3 are simulated and the results show that 1.2 is the optimum (Figure 9).

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Recovery factor and OSR of different production and injection rate ratio

formatted-caption.caption-text: Recovery factor and OSR of different production and injection rate ratio

linkTarget.anchoringText: Because of the permeability of S1-3832 is a little lower than X-VI, the perforation length of injectors can be almost the same or a little longer. Based on the length of 5~8 m of X-VI project, numerical simulations cases of 4m, 6m, 8m, 10m, 12m and 14m are simulated and results show that optimum length is 10m (Figure 10). In addition, according to experiences of SAGD development in Liaohe, the lower part of perforation distance to horizontal wells is 3~5 m in general.

When CSS for vertical wells continues, steam circulation rate of horizontal wells is kept constant. According to simulation results of cases of different cycles of CSS pre-heating (0 cycles, 2 cycles, 4 cycles 6 cycles and 8 cycles), case of 2 cycles got the best performance (Figure 11). Due to simulation results, H-8 temperature distribution is shown in Figure 12.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Recovery factor and OSR curves of different transition time

formatted-caption.caption-text: Recovery factor and OSR curves of different transition time

linkTarget.anchoringText: When CSS for vertical wells continues, steam circulation rate of horizontal wells is kept constant. According to simulation results of cases of different cycles of CSS pre-heating (0 cycles, 2 cycles, 4 cycles 6 cycles and 8 cycles), case of 2 cycles got the best performance (Figure 11). Due to simulation results, H-8 temperature distribution is shown in Figure 12.

H-4 temperature profile is shown in Figure 13. Now the chamber is expanding upwards and laterally, assisted by vertical wells around, viscous drive is more dominant in the beginning and gravity drive will dominate the subsequent part of the development. According to temperature data from observation well of H-8 where shale layers exist, high temperature zone (steam) is expanding to the upper zones of shale layers (shale content is represented by grey curve) in SAGD stage (Figure 14).

H-4 temperature profile is shown in Figure 13. Now the chamber is expanding upwards and laterally, assisted by vertical wells around, viscous drive is more dominant in the beginning and gravity drive will dominate the subsequent part of the development. According to temperature data from observation well of H-8 where shale layers exist, high temperature zone (steam) is expanding to the upper zones of shale layers (shale content is represented by grey curve) in SAGD stage (Figure 14).

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Observation well H-8 temperature profiles (shale content shown by gray lines).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Observation well H-8 temperature profiles (shale content shown by gray lines).
